PHILADELPHIA, Jan. 12. A report of the condition of the American iron trade for the past year has just been completed by James M. Swank, Secretary of the American Iron and Steel Association. It states that the production of pig-iron in the United States in 1877 was 2,314,585 tons, and in 1878 was 2,382,000 tons. Pennsylvania shows an increase of over 100,000 tons, while Ohio shows a decrease of over 30,000 tons.

AUGUSTA, Me., Feb. 16.--Ephraim Hysler and his wife left their home at Somerville, about 30 miles from Augusta, Friday forenoon, to do some trading, leaving their three children, aged respectively 4 years, 2 years, and 8 months, alone in the house. NEWPORT, R.I., May 23. Everything, as far as it can be judged at present, is looking very favorable for the growing crops in this State. The season, however, is about three weeks late, but it is thought that the present warm weather will make up for the backwardness of the Spring.

DENVER, Col., May 23. Reports from all parts of the State show that the growing crops are in good condition, and promise more than an average yield. Grain was late in starting, the month of March having been unusually dry, but frequent rains from the middle of April until now have brought everything forward in good shape.

PORTSMOUTH, N.H., May 23. Grass is looking well for a large crop; apples, small; pears, peaches, cherries, abundant; grain, little raised in this region above local requirements; potatoes and corn, average amounts planted; beans, peas, and root crops, the same.

BALTIMORE, May 22. A week ago the crop prospects of Maryland were seriously jeopardized by a long and unseasonable drought. ST. LOUIS, May 23. The reports of the condition of the growing crop in Missouri vary so much in different localities that it is next to impossible to make more than a very general forecast of what the harvest will be. Even from contiguous counties the accounts are most contradictory.

MILWAUKEE, Wis., May 23. The advices from Wisconsin are not very full, but sufficient information is given to indicate that the crops of small grains in the southern part of the State are rather backward, the rains not being heavy enough to improve their condition.

MEMPHIS, May 23. LE ROY, N.Y., May 30. In April, 1878, James Matthews, of Warsaw, 12 miles south of this place, aided by the Vacuum Oil Company, of Rochester, commenced putting down an oil well at Wyoming, near Warsaw. In October the drill struck a bed of rock salt. The deposit proved to be over 70 feet thick.
